dt: {bc}of the same or a similar kind or nature

{bc}having the property that if each {d_link|variable|variable:2} is replaced by a {d_link|constant|constant:2} {d_link|times|times} that variable the constant can be factored out {bc}having each term of the same degree if all variables are considered

quotes.t: The Benedictine convents for women, which had begun to be founded soon after Benedict's day, became particularly {qword}homogeneous{/qword} in their social composition. The nuns of the ninth and tenth centuries were all high-born ladies, and it was almost impossible to be admitted to these convents without being a widowed or maiden relative of an important lord.

In their natural state, mountains of this type are almost entirely covered by dense forest. The wooded landscape is very uniform, lacking in contrast, and any disturbance of the {qword}homogeneous{/qword} green blanket is very obvious …
One odd side effect is that, during the last 20 years, the formerly {qword}homogeneous{/qword}, rather stodgy world of academic criticism has diversified into an incoherent mob of competing factions.

et: Medieval Latin {it}homogeneus, homogenus{/it}, from Greek {it}homogenēs{/it}, from {it}hom-{/it} + {it}genos{/it} kind {ma}{mat|kin|}{/ma}
shortdef: of the same or a similar kind or nature
of uniform structure or composition throughout
having the property that if each variable is replaced by a constant times that variable the constant can be factored out : having each term of the same degree if all variables are considered
